weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

countermeasure.name: Enable network logging for security investigation

Enable and collect network security group (NSG) resource logs, NSG flow logs, Azure Firewall logs, and Web Application Firewall (WAF) logs, and logs from virtual machines via the network traffic data collection agent for security analysis to support incident investigations, and security alert generation. You can send the flow logs to an Azure Monitor Log Analytics workspace and then use Traffic Analytics to provide insights.
Collect DNS query logs to assist in correlating other network data.

countermeasure.name: Ensure regular automated backups
countermeasure.desc:
For Azure Backup supported resources (such as Azure VMs, SQL Server, HANA databases, Azure PostgreSQL Database, File Shares, Blobs or Disks), enable Azure Backup and configure the desired frequency and retention period. For Azure VM, you can use Azure Policy to have backup automatically enabled using Azure Policy.
For resources or services not supported by Azure Backup, use the native backup capability provided by the resource or service. For example, Azure Key Vault provides a native backup capability.
For resources/services that are neither supported by Azure Backup nor have a native backup capability, evaluate your backup and disaster needs, and create your own mechanism as per your business requirements. For example: - If you use Azure Storage for data storage, enable blob versioning for your storage blobs which will allow you to preserve, retrieve, and restore every version of every object stored in your Azure Storage. - Service configuration settings can usually be exported to Azure Resource Manager templates.

reference.name: Analysis Services database backup and restore
Auto-Enable Backup on VM Creation using Azure Policy

countermeasure.name: Manage application identities securely and automatically
countermeasure.desc:
Use Azure managed identities, which can authenticate to Azure services and resources that support Azure AD authentication. Managed identity credentials are fully managed, rotated, and protected by the platform, avoiding hard-coded credentials in source code or configuration files.
For services that don't support managed identities, use Azure AD to create a service principal with restricted permissions at the resource level. It is recommended to configure service principals with certificate credentials and fall back to client secrets for authentication.

countermeasure.name: Restrict resource access based on conditions
countermeasure.desc:
Use Azure AD conditional access for more granular access controls based on user-defined conditions, such as requiring user logins from certain IP ranges (or devices) to use MFA. Azure AD Conditional Access allows you to enforce access controls on your organizations apps based on certain conditions.
Define the applicable conditions and criteria for Azure AD conditional access in the workload. Consider the following common use cases: - Requiring multi-factor authentication for users with administrative roles - Requiring multi-factor authentication for Azure management tasks - Blocking sign-ins for users attempting to use legacy authentication protocols - Requiring trusted locations for Azure AD Multi-Factor Authentication registration - Blocking or granting access from specific locations - Blocking risky sign-in behaviors - Requiring organization-managed devices for specific applications
Note: Granular authentication session management controls can also be implemented through Azure AD conditional access policies such as sign-in frequency and persistent browser session.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Unconfigured security feature poses risk for unauthorized access
threat.desc:
General threat description
The lack of current Microsoft guidance for a feature configuration can expose the organization to security risks due to potential misconfigurations and lack of recommended security controls. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents could take advantage of the lack of guidance to exploit misconfigurations and weaknesses in the security controls. 
Impacts
The impacts could include unauthorized access, data breaches, and potential disruption of services due to misconfigurations. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker could exploit the lack of guidance to manipulate security settings, gain unauthorized access to sensitive data, and compromise the integrity and availability of systems and services.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1089 - Disabling Security Tools

threat.name: Unauthorized access due to misconfigured Azure AD conditional access
threat.desc:
General threat description
The use of Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) conditional access without proper configuration and management can lead to unauthorized access and security breaches in the workload. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents can exploit misconfigured Azure AD conditional access policies to gain unauthorized access to specific applications or resources. This can be accomplished through techniques such as device spoofing, location manipulation, or leveraging risky sign-in behaviors. 
Impacts
The impacts of misconfigured Azure AD conditional access include unauthorized access to sensitive data, increased risk of account compromise, and potential data breaches. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker may exploit a misconfigured conditional access policy that does not require organization-managed devices for specific applications. By using a non-compliant device or spoofing device information, the attacker could gain unauthorized access to critical resources or sensitive data within the workload.

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Undetected unauthorized activities due to lack of resource logs
threat.desc:
General threat description
The lack of comprehensive resource logs for the service increases the difficulty in detecting unauthorized access, malicious activities, or potential security incidents.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents can exploit the absence of resource logs to perform unauthorized actions, access sensitive data, or compromise the integrity and availability of the service. Attack vectors may include attempts to access secrets, sensitive information, or execute unauthorized commands within the service.
Impacts
The absence of detailed resource logs increases the risk of undetected security breaches, unauthorized access to sensitive data, and compromised service integrity. This can result in data leaks, compliance violations, and reputational damage.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to a Key Vault and retrieves sensitive secrets undetected due to the absence of resource logs, resulting in unauthorized access to critical information. Another scenario involves an attacker exploiting the lack of resource logs in an Azure SQL database to perform undetected malicious activities, potentially leading to data exfiltration or service disruption.

weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-321
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-321: Use of Hard-coded Cryptographic Key The use of a hard-coded cryptographic key significantly increases the possibility that encrypted data may be recovered.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

weakness.name: CWE-922
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-922: Insecure Storage of Sensitive Information The product stores sensitive information without properly limiting read or write access by unauthorized actors. If read access is not properly restricted, then attackers can steal the sensitive information. If write access is not properly restricted, then attackers can modify and possibly delete the data, causing incorrect results and possibly a denial of service.

weakness.name: CWE-923
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-923: Improper Restriction of Communication Channel to Intended Endpoints The product establishes a communication channel to (or from) an endpoint for privileged or protected operations, but it does not properly ensure that it is communicating with the correct endpoint.

countermeasure.name: Enable threat detection capabilities
countermeasure.desc:
Use the threat detection capability of Microsoft Defender for Cloud for the respective Azure services.
For threat detection not included in Microsoft Defender services, refer to Microsoft Cloud Security Benchmark service baselines for the respective services to enable the threat detection or security alert capabilities within the service. Ingest alerts and log data from Microsoft Defender for Cloud, Microsoft 365 Defender, and log data from other resources into your Azure Monitor or Microsoft Sentinel instances to build analytics rules, which hunt detect threats and create alerts that match specific criteria across your environment.
For Operational Technology (OT) environments that include computers that control or monitor Industrial Control System (ICS) or Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) resources, use Microsoft Defender for IoT to inventory assets and detect threats and vulnerabilities.
For services that do not have a native threat detection capability, consider collecting the data plane logs and analyze the threats through Microsoft Sentinel.

countermeasure.name: Establish network segmentation boundaries
countermeasure.desc:
Create a virtual network (VNet) as a fundamental segmentation approach in your Azure network, so resources such as VMs can be deployed into the VNet within a network boundary. To further segment the network, you can create subnets inside VNet for smaller sub-networks.
Use network security groups (NSG) as a network layer control to restrict or monitor traffic by port, protocol, source IP address, or destination IP address. Refer to NS-7 Simplify network security configuration to use Adaptive Network Hardening to recommend NSG hardening rules based on threat intelligence and traffic analysis result.
You can also use application security groups (ASGs) to simplify complex configuration. Instead of defining policy based on explicit IP addresses in network security groups, ASGs enable you to configure network security as a natural extension of an application's structure, allowing you to group virtual machines and define network security policies based on those groups.

countermeasure.name: Follow just enough administration (least privilege) principle
countermeasure.desc:
Use Azure role-based access control (Azure RBAC) to manage Azure resource access through role assignments. Through RBAC, you can assign roles to users, groups, service principals, and managed identities. There are pre-defined built-in roles for certain resources, and these roles can be inventoried or queried through tools such as Azure CLI, Azure PowerShell, and the Azure portal.
The privileges you assign to resources through Azure RBAC should always be limited to what's required by the roles. Limited privileges will complement the just-in-time (JIT) approach of Azure AD Privileged Identity Management (PIM), and those privileges should be reviewed periodically. If required, you can also use PIM to define a time-bound assignment, which is a condition in a role assignment where a user can only activate the role within the specified start and end dates.
Note: Use Azure built-in roles to allocate permissions and only create custom roles when required.

Use Azure managed identities, which can authenticate to Azure services and resources that support Azure AD authentication. Managed identity credentials are fully managed, rotated, and protected by the platform, avoiding hard-coded credentials in source code or configuration files.
For services that don't support managed identities, use Azure AD to create a service principal with restricted permissions at the resource level. It is recommended to configure service principals with certificate credentials and fall back to client secrets for authentication.

countermeasure.name: Restrict resource access based on conditions
countermeasure.desc:
Use Azure AD conditional access for more granular access controls based on user-defined conditions, such as requiring user logins from certain IP ranges (or devices) to use MFA. Azure AD Conditional Access allows you to enforce access controls on your organizations apps based on certain conditions.
Define the applicable conditions and criteria for Azure AD conditional access in the workload. Consider the following common use cases: - Requiring multi-factor authentication for users with administrative roles - Requiring multi-factor authentication for Azure management tasks - Blocking sign-ins for users attempting to use legacy authentication protocols - Requiring trusted locations for Azure AD Multi-Factor Authentication registration - Blocking or granting access from specific locations - Blocking risky sign-in behaviors - Requiring organization-managed devices for specific applications
Note: Granular authentication session management controls can also be implemented through Azure AD conditional access policies such as sign-in frequency and persistent browser session.

countermeasure.name: Secure cloud native services with network controls
countermeasure.desc:
Deploy private endpoints for all Azure resources that support the Private Link feature, to establish a private access point for the resources. Using Private Link will keep the private connection from routing through the public network.
Note: Certain Azure services may also allow private communication through the service endpoint feature, though it is recommended to use Azure Private Link for secure and private access to services hosted on Azure platform.
For certain services, you can choose to deploy VNet integration for the service where you can restrict/isolate the VNET to establish a private access point for the service.
You also have the option to configure the service native network ACL rules or simply disable public network access to block access from the public network.
For Azure VMs, unless there is a strong use case, you should avoid assigning public IPs/subnet directly to the VM interface and instead use gateway or load balancer services as the front-end for access by the public network.

countermeasure.name: Use a secure key management process
countermeasure.desc:
Use Azure Key Vault to create and control your encryption keys life cycle, including key generation, distribution, and storage. Rotate and revoke your keys in Azure Key Vault and your service based on the defined schedule and when there is a key retirement or compromise. Require a certain cryptographic type and minimum key size when generating keys.
When there is a need to use customer-managed key (CMK) in the workload services or applications, ensure you follow the best practices: - Use a key hierarchy to generate a separate data encryption key (DEK) with your key encryption key (KEK) in your key vault. - Ensure keys are registered with Azure Key Vault and implemented via key IDs in each service or application.
To maximize the key material lifetime and portability, bring your own key (BYOK) to the services (i.e., importing HSM-protected keys from your on-premises HSMs into Azure Key Vault). Follow the recommended guideline to perform the key generation and key transfer.
Note: Refer to the below for the FIPS 140-2 level for Azure Key Vault types and FIPS compliance/validation level. - Software-protected keys in vaults (Premium & Standard SKUs): FIPS 140-2 Level 1 - HSM-protected keys in vaults (Premium SKU): FIPS 140-2 Level 2 - HSM-protected keys in Managed HSM: FIPS 140-2 Level 3 Azure Key Vault Premium uses a shared HSM infrastructure in the backend. Azure Key Vault Managed HSM uses dedicated, confidential service endpoints with a dedicated HSM for when you need a higher level of key security.

countermeasure.name: Use centralized identity and authentication system
countermeasure.desc:
Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) is Azure's identity and authentication management service. You should standardize on Azure AD to govern your organization's identity and authentication in: - Microsoft cloud resources, such as Azure Storage, Azure Virtual Machines (Linux and Windows), Azure Key Vault, PaaS, and SaaS applications. - Your organization's resources, such as applications on Azure, third-party applications running on your corporate network resources, and third-party SaaS applications. - Your enterprise identities in Active Directory by synchronization to Azure AD to ensure a consistent and centrally managed identity strategy.
For the Azure services that apply, avoid use of local authentication methods and instead use Azure Active Directory to centralize your service authentications.
Note: As soon as it is technically feasible, you should migrate on-premises Active Directory-based applications to Azure AD. This could be an Azure AD Enterprise Directory, Business to Business configuration, or Business to consumer configuration.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Undefined Microsoft feature configuration may lead to security vulnerabilities
threat.desc:
General threat description
The lack of guidance in implementing a control may result in misconfigurations or oversights that can lead to security vulnerabilities in the organization's environment. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Internal and external threat actors may exploit the lack of guidance to identify and target misconfigured security features. Attack vectors may include phishing, social engineering, and direct exploitation of misconfigured settings. 
Impacts
The impacts of misconfiguring security features due to the lack of guidance may include unauthorized access, data breaches, service disruptions, and potential compliance violations. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker exploits a misconfigured security feature, such as access controls, due to the absence of guidance, gaining unauthorized access to sensitive data or critical systems.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized data exfiltration attempts from Azure Cosmos DB
threat.desc:
General threat description
Data exfiltration attempts may occur when unauthorized individuals or entities attempt to access and steal sensitive data from a cloud environment. This can include customer information, financial records, intellectual property, and other valuable data. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include malicious insiders, external attackers, or individuals with unauthorized access to the cloud environment. Attack vectors could involve exploiting misconfigured access controls, weaknesses in data encryption, or leveraging vulnerabilities in the Azure Cosmos DB service. 
Impacts
The impact of successful data exfiltration attempts can be severe, leading to financial loss, reputational damage, regulatory non-compliance, and legal repercussions. It can also result in the compromise of sensitive customer information, which can erode trust and customer confidence. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker exploits misconfigured access controls in the Azure Cosmos DB service to gain unauthorized access to sensitive data. They then attempt to exfiltrate this data by bypassing encryption controls or leveraging vulnerabilities in the service to copy the data to an external location. This could result in the unauthorized access and theft of sensitive information, leading to severe consequences for the organization and its customers.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to Azure Cosmos DB through public network exposure
threat.desc:
General threat description
Disabling public network access and deploying private endpoints for Azure resources can help mitigate threats related to unauthorized access and exposure of sensitive data to the public internet. However, it's important to understand potential threats to the virtual network and the Azure Cosmos DB account despite these controls. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may attempt to bypass the network controls by exploiting misconfigurations, weak authentication methods, or leveraging insider access. Attack vectors may include network reconnaissance, unauthorized access attempts to the Azure Cosmos DB account, and potential internal threats within the virtual network. 
Impacts
The impacts of these threats could result in unauthorized access to sensitive data stored in Azure Cosmos DB, potential data exfiltration, and compromise of the virtual network's integrity. This could lead to regulatory compliance violations, reputational damage, and financial loss for the organization. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains unauthorized access to the virtual network by exploiting weak credentials of a legitimate user or leveraging a misconfigured network security group. Once inside the network, they attempt to access the Azure Cosmos DB account through its public IPs, potentially gaining access to sensitive data or executing data manipulation attacks. Alternatively, an insider threat with access to the virtual network might deliberately bypass the private endpoint controls to exfiltrate data from Azure Cosmos DB.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Undefined Microsoft feature configuration exposes organization to unauthorized access
threat.desc:
General threat description
The lack of guidance for a specific feature configuration in Microsoft environments poses a potential threat to the security posture of the organization. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents could include malicious actors exploiting the lack of guidance to configure the feature in a vulnerable manner. Attack vectors may include unauthorized access, data breaches, or disruption of services. 
Impacts
The impacts of the lack of guidance on feature configuration could lead to security misconfigurations, increased vulnerability to attacks, and potential exposure of sensitive data. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker could exploit the lack of guidance to misconfigure the feature, leading to unauthorized access to sensitive data or disruption of critical services.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1562.001 - Disable or Modify Tools

threat.name: Unauthorized access due to improper identity management policy
threat.desc:
General threat description
The lack of current guidance from Microsoft regarding a feature configuration can lead to potential security vulnerabilities and misconfigurations within an organization's cloud environment. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may take advantage of the lack of clear guidance to intentionally or inadvertently misconfigure the security feature. Attack vectors could include malicious actors exploiting misconfigurations or inadvertent errors by authorized personnel. 
Impacts
The impacts of misconfiguration due to the absence of current guidance include increased risk of unauthorized access, data breaches, service interruptions, and potential compliance violations. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker could exploit the lack of guidance to manipulate the configuration in a way that enables unauthorized access to sensitive data or resources. Additionally, an authorized user may inadvertently misconfigure the security feature, leading to unintended exposure of sensitive information.

threat.name: Undetected unauthorized activities due to lack of resource logs
threat.desc:
General threat description
Implementing Microsoft Defender for Azure Cosmos DB and enabling resource logs can help mitigate threats such as unauthorized access, data breaches, and malicious activities targeting the database. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include unauthorized users, malicious insiders, and external attackers targeting Azure Cosmos DB through various means such as SQL injection, NoSQL injection, and exploiting misconfigured access permissions. 
Impacts
The impacts of these threats include unauthorized data access, data manipulation, data exfiltration, and potential disruptions to the database service, leading to financial loss, reputational damage, and compliance violations. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains unauthorized access to Azure Cosmos DB and exfiltrates sensitive customer data. Alternatively, a malicious insider exploits their privileges to manipulate data within the database without detection.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1562.008 - Disable or Modify Cloud Logs

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-321
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-321: Use of Hard-coded Cryptographic Key The use of a hard-coded cryptographic key significantly increases the possibility that encrypted data may be recovered.

weakness.name: CWE-359
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-359: Exposure of Private Personal Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product does not properly prevent a person's private, personal information from being accessed by actors who either (1) are not explicitly authorized to access the information or (2) do not have the implicit consent of the person about whom the information is collected.

weakness.name: CWE-522
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-522: Insufficiently Protected Credentials The product transmits or stores authentication credentials, but it uses an insecure method that is susceptible to unauthorized interception and/or retrieval.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

weakness.name: CWE-922
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-922: Insecure Storage of Sensitive Information The product stores sensitive information without properly limiting read or write access by unauthorized actors. If read access is not properly restricted, then attackers can steal the sensitive information. If write access is not properly restricted, then attackers can modify and possibly delete the data, causing incorrect results and possibly a denial of service.

weakness.name: CWE-923
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-923: Improper Restriction of Communication Channel to Intended Endpoints The product establishes a communication channel to (or from) an endpoint for privileged or protected operations, but it does not properly ensure that it is communicating with the correct endpoint.

countermeasure.name: Encrypt sensitive data in transit
countermeasure.desc:
Enforce secure transfer in services such as Azure Storage, where a native data in transit encryption feature is built in.
Enforce HTTPS for web application workloads and services by ensuring that any clients connecting to your Azure resources use transport layer security (TLS) v1.2 or later. For remote management of VMs, use SSH (for Linux) or RDP/TLS (for Windows) instead of an unencrypted protocol.
For remote management of Azure virtual machines, use SSH (for Linux) or RDP/TLS (for Windows) instead of an unencrypted protocol. For secure file transfer, use the SFTP/FTPS service in Azure Storage Blob, App Service apps, and Function apps, instead of using the regular FTP service.
Note: Data in transit encryption is enabled for all Azure traffic traveling between Azure datacenters. TLS v1.2 or later is enabled on most Azure services by default. And some services such as Azure Storage and Application Gateway can enforce TLS v1.2 or later on the server side.

countermeasure.name: Ensure regular automated backups
countermeasure.desc:
For Azure Backup supported resources (such as Azure VMs, SQL Server, HANA databases, Azure PostgreSQL Database, File Shares, Blobs or Disks), enable Azure Backup and configure the desired frequency and retention period. For Azure VM, you can use Azure Policy to have backup automatically enabled using Azure Policy.
For resources or services not supported by Azure Backup, use the native backup capability provided by the resource or service. For example, Azure Key Vault provides a native backup capability.
For resources/services that are neither supported by Azure Backup nor have a native backup capability, evaluate your backup and disaster needs, and create your own mechanism as per your business requirements. For example: - If you use Azure Storage for data storage, enable blob versioning for your storage blobs which will allow you to preserve, retrieve, and restore every version of every object stored in your Azure Storage. - Service configuration settings can usually be exported to Azure Resource Manager templates.

countermeasure.name: Establish network segmentation boundaries
countermeasure.desc:
Create a virtual network (VNet) as a fundamental segmentation approach in your Azure network, so resources such as VMs can be deployed into the VNet within a network boundary. To further segment the network, you can create subnets inside VNet for smaller sub-networks.
Use network security groups (NSG) as a network layer control to restrict or monitor traffic by port, protocol, source IP address, or destination IP address. Refer to NS-7 Simplify network security configuration to use Adaptive Network Hardening to recommend NSG hardening rules based on threat intelligence and traffic analysis result.
You can also use application security groups (ASGs) to simplify complex configuration. Instead of defining policy based on explicit IP addresses in network security groups, ASGs enable you to configure network security as a natural extension of an application's structure, allowing you to group virtual machines and define network security policies based on those groups.

countermeasure.name: Manage application identities securely and automatically
countermeasure.desc:
Use Azure managed identities, which can authenticate to Azure services and resources that support Azure AD authentication. Managed identity credentials are fully managed, rotated, and protected by the platform, avoiding hard-coded credentials in source code or configuration files.
For services that don't support managed identities, use Azure AD to create a service principal with restricted permissions at the resource level. It is recommended to configure service principals with certificate credentials and fall back to client secrets for authentication.

countermeasure.name: Restrict the exposure of credential and secrets
countermeasure.desc:
When using a managed identity is not an option, ensure that secrets and credentials are stored in secure locations such as Azure Key Vault, instead of embedding them into the code and configuration files.
If you use Azure DevOps and GitHub for your code management platform: - Implement Azure DevOps Credential Scanner to identify credentials within the code. - For GitHub, use the native secret scanning feature to identify credentials or other forms of secrets within the code.
Clients such as Azure Functions, Azure Apps services, and VMs can use managed identities to access Azure Key Vault securely. See Data Protection controls related to the use of Azure Key Vault for secrets management.
Note: Azure Key Vault provides automatic rotation for supported services. For secrets which cannot be automatically rotated, ensure they are manually rotated periodically and purged when no longer in use.

countermeasure.name: Secure cloud native services with network controls
countermeasure.desc:
Deploy private endpoints for all Azure resources that support the Private Link feature, to establish a private access point for the resources. Using Private Link will keep the private connection from routing through the public network.
Note: Certain Azure services may also allow private communication through the service endpoint feature, though it is recommended to use Azure Private Link for secure and private access to services hosted on Azure platform.
For certain services, you can choose to deploy VNet integration for the service where you can restrict/isolate the VNET to establish a private access point for the service.
You also have the option to configure the service native network ACL rules or simply disable public network access to block access from the public network.
For Azure VMs, unless there is a strong use case, you should avoid assigning public IPs/subnet directly to the VM interface and instead use gateway or load balancer services as the front-end for access by the public network.

countermeasure.name: Use a secure key management process
countermeasure.desc:
Use Azure Key Vault to create and control your encryption keys life cycle, including key generation, distribution, and storage. Rotate and revoke your keys in Azure Key Vault and your service based on the defined schedule and when there is a key retirement or compromise. Require a certain cryptographic type and minimum key size when generating keys.
When there is a need to use customer-managed key (CMK) in the workload services or applications, ensure you follow the best practices: - Use a key hierarchy to generate a separate data encryption key (DEK) with your key encryption key (KEK) in your key vault. - Ensure keys are registered with Azure Key Vault and implemented via key IDs in each service or application.
To maximize the key material lifetime and portability, bring your own key (BYOK) to the services (i.e., importing HSM-protected keys from your on-premises HSMs into Azure Key Vault). Follow the recommended guideline to perform the key generation and key transfer.
Note: Refer to the below for the FIPS 140-2 level for Azure Key Vault types and FIPS compliance/validation level. - Software-protected keys in vaults (Premium & Standard SKUs): FIPS 140-2 Level 1 - HSM-protected keys in vaults (Premium SKU): FIPS 140-2 Level 2 - HSM-protected keys in Managed HSM: FIPS 140-2 Level 3 Azure Key Vault Premium uses a shared HSM infrastructure in the backend. Azure Key Vault Managed HSM uses dedicated, confidential service endpoints with a dedicated HSM for when you need a higher level of key security.

Azure data encryption at rest--Key Hierarchy
BYOK(Bring Your Own Key) specification

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Azure policy misconfiguration allows unauthorized resource access
threat.desc:
General threat description
Misconfigured Azure resources can lead to security vulnerabilities and non-compliance with organizational standards, resulting in unauthorized access, data breaches, and other security incidents. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat actors can exploit misconfigured Azure resources through various attack vectors such as unauthorized access, data exfiltration, privilege escalation, and denial of service attacks. 
Impacts
The impacts of misconfigured Azure resources include unauthorized access to sensitive data, service disruptions, regulatory non-compliance, reputational damage, and financial losses. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker leverages a misconfigured Azure storage account with public access to exfiltrate sensitive data. In another scenario, an adversary exploits a misconfigured virtual network security group to gain unauthorized access to virtual machines.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1578.005 - Modify Cloud Compute Configurations||ATLAS - AML.TA0004 - Initial Access

threat.name: Unauthorized access to sensitive data due to poor encryption and key management
threat.desc:
General threat description
The threat of unauthorized access to sensitive data at rest and in transit arises when encryption, key management, and secure transfer protocols are not properly implemented and managed. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents could include malicious actors, hackers, or insiders with unauthorized access, who could exploit vulnerabilities in the encryption, key management, or secure transfer protocols to gain unauthorized access to sensitive data. 
Impacts
The impact of this threat includes unauthorized disclosure of sensitive data, potential compliance violations, reputational damage, financial losses, and compromised integrity and confidentiality of the data. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker could intercept unencrypted data during transit or gain unauthorized access to data at rest due to weak encryption or compromised keys. They could also exploit outdated protocols to perform man-in-the-middle attacks and compromise the confidentiality and integrity of the data. Additionally, if keys are not properly managed, an attacker could gain unauthorized access to the keys, leading to unauthorized decryption of encrypted data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1022 - Data Encrypted||ATLAS - AML.T0055 - Unsecured Credentials

threat.name: Exposure of embedded credentials and secrets in code and configuration
threat.desc:
General threat description
Storing secrets and credentials in insecure locations or embedding them into code or configuration files poses a significant security risk. Unauthorized access to these sensitive materials can lead to data breaches, service disruption, or unauthorized access to resources. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents could include malicious insiders, external attackers, or unauthorized users who attempt to access and exploit stored credentials. Attack vectors may include unauthorized access to code repositories, exploitation of misconfigured permissions, or interception of configuration files during transit. 
Impacts
The impacts of compromised secrets and credentials can range from unauthorized access to critical resources, data breaches, financial losses, service downtime, or reputational damage. Additionally, leaked credentials can result in privilege escalation and lateral movement within an environment. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains unauthorized access to a code repository and extracts hard-coded credentials, allowing them to compromise sensitive data stored in an Azure service. Alternatively, an attacker intercepts a configuration file being transmitted over an insecure channel, obtaining credentials that provide access to critical cloud resources.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1552 - Unsecured Credentials||ATLAS - AML.T0055 - Unsecured Credentials

threat.name: Unauthorized data access during support scenarios by Microsoft engineers
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized access to sensitive data by Microsoft support personnel or other threat actors. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
- Microsoft support personnel with excessive privileges - External attackers gaining unauthorized access to support tools or exploiting vulnerabilities 
Impacts
- Unauthorized disclosure of sensitive information - Violation of data privacy regulations - Reputational damage 
Example Attack Scenarios
- A rogue support personnel bypasses controls and access sensitive customer data without proper authorization. - An external attacker exploits vulnerabilities in support tools to gain unauthorized access to customer data during a legitimate support request.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1078 - Valid Accounts||ATLAS - AML.T0044 - Full AI Model Access

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Undetected unauthorized activities due to lack of resource logs
threat.desc:
General threat description
The lack of comprehensive resource logs for the service increases the difficulty in detecting unauthorized access, malicious activities, or potential security incidents.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents can exploit the absence of resource logs to perform unauthorized actions, access sensitive data, or compromise the integrity and availability of the service. Attack vectors may include attempts to access secrets, sensitive information, or execute unauthorized commands within the service.
Impacts
The absence of detailed resource logs increases the risk of undetected security breaches, unauthorized access to sensitive data, and compromised service integrity. This can result in data leaks, compliance violations, and reputational damage.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to a Key Vault and retrieves sensitive secrets undetected due to the absence of resource logs, resulting in unauthorized access to critical information. Another scenario involves an attacker exploiting the lack of resource logs in an Azure SQL database to perform undetected malicious activities, potentially leading to data exfiltration or service disruption.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1562.008 - Disable or Modify Cloud Logs||ATLAS - AML.T0004 - Search Application Repositories

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Unauthorized access through open ports and unapproved IP addresses
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized Access to Azure Databricks Data Plane Resources 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents could include malicious actors attempting to bypass IP access lists or exploit misconfigured network security groups (NSGs). Attack vectors may involve direct attempts to access Azure Databricks data plane resources from unapproved IP addresses, or circumventing NSG restrictions through network-related attacks. 
Impacts
The impacts could include unauthorized access to data and workloads, potential data breaches, unauthorized manipulation of data, and potential disruption of services running on Azure Databricks. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker could attempt to bypass the IP access lists by spoofing an approved IP address or finding a vulnerability in the network security group (NSG) configuration to gain unauthorized access to Azure Databricks data plane resources. Another scenario might involve leveraging misconfigured NSG rules to gain access to management ports from untrusted networks, potentially leading to unauthorized access and compromise of sensitive data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application||ATLAS - AML.T0006 - Active Scanning

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Unmitigated Microsoft feature configuration increases security risk
threat.desc:
General threat description
The lack of current Microsoft guidance for a specific feature configuration could lead to potential security threats and vulnerabilities within the organization's cloud environment. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents could exploit the absence of guidance to exploit misconfigurations, implement unauthorized changes, and potentially gain unauthorized access to sensitive data or resources. Attack vectors may involve insiders with malicious intent, external attackers, or inadvertent human errors due to lack of clear guidelines. 
Impacts
The impacts of not having current Microsoft guidance for a feature configuration include potential data breaches, service disruptions, compliance violations, and reputational damage for the organization. 
Example Attack Scenarios
A malicious insider could take advantage of the lack of guidance to intentionally misconfigure the feature, leading to unauthorized access to sensitive data. An external attacker could use this gap to exploit vulnerabilities and gain unauthorized access to the organization's cloud environment.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-321
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-321: Use of Hard-coded Cryptographic Key The use of a hard-coded cryptographic key significantly increases the possibility that encrypted data may be recovered.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

weakness.name: CWE-922
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-922: Insecure Storage of Sensitive Information The product stores sensitive information without properly limiting read or write access by unauthorized actors. If read access is not properly restricted, then attackers can steal the sensitive information. If write access is not properly restricted, then attackers can modify and possibly delete the data, causing incorrect results and possibly a denial of service.

weakness.name: CWE-923
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-923: Improper Restriction of Communication Channel to Intended Endpoints The product establishes a communication channel to (or from) an endpoint for privileged or protected operations, but it does not properly ensure that it is communicating with the correct endpoint.

countermeasure.name: Enable network logging for security investigation
countermeasure.desc:
Enable and collect network security group (NSG) resource logs, NSG flow logs, Azure Firewall logs, and Web Application Firewall (WAF) logs, and logs from virtual machines via the network traffic data collection agent for security analysis to support incident investigations, and security alert generation. You can send the flow logs to an Azure Monitor Log Analytics workspace and then use Traffic Analytics to provide insights.
Collect DNS query logs to assist in correlating other network data.

countermeasure.name: Establish network segmentation boundaries
countermeasure.desc:
Create a virtual network (VNet) as a fundamental segmentation approach in your Azure network, so resources such as VMs can be deployed into the VNet within a network boundary. To further segment the network, you can create subnets inside VNet for smaller sub-networks.
Use network security groups (NSG) as a network layer control to restrict or monitor traffic by port, protocol, source IP address, or destination IP address. Refer to NS-7 Simplify network security configuration to use Adaptive Network Hardening to recommend NSG hardening rules based on threat intelligence and traffic analysis result.
You can also use application security groups (ASGs) to simplify complex configuration. Instead of defining policy based on explicit IP addresses in network security groups, ASGs enable you to configure network security as a natural extension of an application's structure, allowing you to group virtual machines and define network security policies based on those groups.

countermeasure.name: Follow just enough administration (least privilege) principle
countermeasure.desc:
Use Azure role-based access control (Azure RBAC) to manage Azure resource access through role assignments. Through RBAC, you can assign roles to users, groups, service principals, and managed identities. There are pre-defined built-in roles for certain resources, and these roles can be inventoried or queried through tools such as Azure CLI, Azure PowerShell, and the Azure portal.
The privileges you assign to resources through Azure RBAC should always be limited to what's required by the roles. Limited privileges will complement the just-in-time (JIT) approach of Azure AD Privileged Identity Management (PIM), and those privileges should be reviewed periodically. If required, you can also use PIM to define a time-bound assignment, which is a condition in a role assignment where a user can only activate the role within the specified start and end dates.
Note: Use Azure built-in roles to allocate permissions and only create custom roles when required.

countermeasure.name: Manage application identities securely and automatically
countermeasure.desc:
Use Azure managed identities, which can authenticate to Azure services and resources that support Azure AD authentication. Managed identity credentials are fully managed, rotated, and protected by the platform, avoiding hard-coded credentials in source code or configuration files.
For services that don't support managed identities, use Azure AD to create a service principal with restricted permissions at the resource level. It is recommended to configure service principals with certificate credentials and fall back to client secrets for authentication.

countermeasure.name: Restrict resource access based on conditions
countermeasure.desc:
Use Azure AD conditional access for more granular access controls based on user-defined conditions, such as requiring user logins from certain IP ranges (or devices) to use MFA. Azure AD Conditional Access allows you to enforce access controls on your organizations apps based on certain conditions.
Define the applicable conditions and criteria for Azure AD conditional access in the workload. Consider the following common use cases: - Requiring multi-factor authentication for users with administrative roles - Requiring multi-factor authentication for Azure management tasks - Blocking sign-ins for users attempting to use legacy authentication protocols - Requiring trusted locations for Azure AD Multi-Factor Authentication registration - Blocking or granting access from specific locations - Blocking risky sign-in behaviors - Requiring organization-managed devices for specific applications
Note: Granular authentication session management controls can also be implemented through Azure AD conditional access policies such as sign-in frequency and persistent browser session.

countermeasure.name: Secure cloud native services with network controls
countermeasure.desc:
Deploy private endpoints for all Azure resources that support the Private Link feature, to establish a private access point for the resources. Using Private Link will keep the private connection from routing through the public network.
Note: Certain Azure services may also allow private communication through the service endpoint feature, though it is recommended to use Azure Private Link for secure and private access to services hosted on Azure platform.
For certain services, you can choose to deploy VNet integration for the service where you can restrict/isolate the VNET to establish a private access point for the service.
You also have the option to configure the service native network ACL rules or simply disable public network access to block access from the public network.
For Azure VMs, unless there is a strong use case, you should avoid assigning public IPs/subnet directly to the VM interface and instead use gateway or load balancer services as the front-end for access by the public network.

countermeasure.name: Use a secure key management process
countermeasure.desc:
Use Azure Key Vault to create and control your encryption keys life cycle, including key generation, distribution, and storage. Rotate and revoke your keys in Azure Key Vault and your service based on the defined schedule and when there is a key retirement or compromise. Require a certain cryptographic type and minimum key size when generating keys.
When there is a need to use customer-managed key (CMK) in the workload services or applications, ensure you follow the best practices: - Use a key hierarchy to generate a separate data encryption key (DEK) with your key encryption key (KEK) in your key vault. - Ensure keys are registered with Azure Key Vault and implemented via key IDs in each service or application.
To maximize the key material lifetime and portability, bring your own key (BYOK) to the services (i.e., importing HSM-protected keys from your on-premises HSMs into Azure Key Vault). Follow the recommended guideline to perform the key generation and key transfer.
Note: Refer to the below for the FIPS 140-2 level for Azure Key Vault types and FIPS compliance/validation level. - Software-protected keys in vaults (Premium & Standard SKUs): FIPS 140-2 Level 1 - HSM-protected keys in vaults (Premium SKU): FIPS 140-2 Level 2 - HSM-protected keys in Managed HSM: FIPS 140-2 Level 3 Azure Key Vault Premium uses a shared HSM infrastructure in the backend. Azure Key Vault Managed HSM uses dedicated, confidential service endpoints with a dedicated HSM for when you need a higher level of key security.

countermeasure.name: Use centralized identity and authentication system
countermeasure.desc:
Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) is Azure's identity and authentication management service. You should standardize on Azure AD to govern your organization's identity and authentication in: - Microsoft cloud resources, such as Azure Storage, Azure Virtual Machines (Linux and Windows), Azure Key Vault, PaaS, and SaaS applications. - Your organization's resources, such as applications on Azure, third-party applications running on your corporate network resources, and third-party SaaS applications. - Your enterprise identities in Active Directory by synchronization to Azure AD to ensure a consistent and centrally managed identity strategy.
For the Azure services that apply, avoid use of local authentication methods and instead use Azure Active Directory to centralize your service authentications.
Note: As soon as it is technically feasible, you should migrate on-premises Active Directory-based applications to Azure AD. This could be an Azure AD Enterprise Directory, Business to Business configuration, or Business to consumer configuration.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Unauthorized access and privilege escalation due to improper use of Azure AD conditional access
threat.desc:
General threat description
The misuse of Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) conditional access and the lack of utilizing managed identities can lead to unauthorized access, privilege escalation, and exploitation of vulnerabilities in the Azure environment.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents can exploit misconfigured or unenforced conditional access policies within Azure AD to gain unauthorized access to data or resources. Attack vectors can include exploiting weaknesses in device authentication, leveraging risky sign-in behavior, or bypassing location-based access controls.
Impacts
The impacts of these threats can include unauthorized data access, data exfiltration, privilege escalation, and compromise of Azure resources. Additionally, the lack of managed identities can lead to the exposure of credentials, enabling attackers to access Azure services and resources.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker could exploit a misconfigured Azure AD conditional access policy to bypass location-based restrictions and gain access to sensitive data from an unauthorized location. Alternatively, an attacker could abuse unmanaged identities to capture and use credentials from compromised Azure resources, leading to further unauthorized access and potential data breaches.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to Azure resources through misconfigured Azure RBAC roles
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized access to Azure resources and data can occur when proper controls are not in place to manage access through Azure RBAC. Attackers may exploit misconfigurations or vulnerabilities to gain access to sensitive resources, leading to potential data breaches or disruption of services.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include external attackers, insiders with malicious intent, or unauthorized users with access to Azure environments. Attack vectors may include brute-force attacks, stolen credentials, misconfigured permissions, or exploitation of vulnerabilities in Azure RBAC.
Impacts
The impacts of unauthorized access through Azure RBAC include potential data exfiltration, tampering with sensitive information, service disruptions, financial loss, reputation damage, and non-compliance with regulatory requirements.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to an Azure resource group by exploiting a misconfigured Azure RBAC role assignment, allowing them to extract sensitive customer data. Alternatively, an insider with unauthorized access abuses their permissions to modify critical resources, resulting in service downtime and operational impact.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Customer-managed encryption key lifecycle management and best practices
threat.desc:
General threat description
The unauthorized access to sensitive data at rest due to compromised or mismanaged encryption keys poses a threat to the confidentiality and integrity of the data.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include malicious insiders, external attackers, or unauthorized third parties who gain access to encryption keys through unauthorized means, such as phishing attacks, social engineering, or exploiting vulnerabilities in the key management processes.
Impacts
The compromise of encryption keys could lead to unauthorized access to sensitive data, potential data exfiltration, and unauthorized modifications to the encrypted data. This could result in non-compliance with regulatory requirements, financial loss, reputational damage, and legal consequences.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains unauthorized access to the customer-managed encryption keys stored in the Azure Key Vault through social engineering tactics targeting the key administrators. With access to the keys, the attacker decrypts and exfiltrates sensitive data at rest, resulting in a data breach and potential compliance violations.

threat.name: Unauthorized access due to not using service tags and private endpoints
threat.desc:
General threat description
Implementing service tags and private endpoints helps mitigate the risk of unauthorized access and potential data exfiltration by restricting network traffic to specified Azure services and establishing private access points for resources.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthorized users or malicious actors may attempt to gain access to Azure resources by bypassing network security controls. They could try to identify specific IP addresses of resources or exploit network vulnerabilities to gain unauthorized access to sensitive data.
Impacts
Failure to utilize service tags and private endpoints could lead to unauthorized access to Azure resources, potential data breaches, and exposure of sensitive information to unauthorized parties.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker may attempt to identify and target specific IP addresses of Azure resources to bypass network security controls and gain unauthorized access. Without private endpoints, sensitive data within Azure resources could be exposed to malicious actors. By bypassing security rules, an attacker could potentially exfiltrate data from Azure services, compromising confidentiality and integrity.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1046 - Network Service Discovery

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Undetected unauthorized activities due to lack of resource logs
threat.desc:
General threat description
The lack of comprehensive resource logs for the service increases the difficulty in detecting unauthorized access, malicious activities, or potential security incidents.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents can exploit the absence of resource logs to perform unauthorized actions, access sensitive data, or compromise the integrity and availability of the service. Attack vectors may include attempts to access secrets, sensitive information, or execute unauthorized commands within the service.
Impacts
The absence of detailed resource logs increases the risk of undetected security breaches, unauthorized access to sensitive data, and compromised service integrity. This can result in data leaks, compliance violations, and reputational damage.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to a Key Vault and retrieves sensitive secrets undetected due to the absence of resource logs, resulting in unauthorized access to critical information. Another scenario involves an attacker exploiting the lack of resource logs in an Azure SQL database to perform undetected malicious activities, potentially leading to data exfiltration or service disruption.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1562.008 - Disable or Modify Cloud Logs

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Unauthorized access due to misconfigured Azure resources
threat.desc:
General threat description
Misconfigurations in cloud resources can lead to security vulnerabilities and unauthorized access, potentially resulting in data breaches, service disruptions, and compliance violations.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents could include malicious actors looking for misconfigured resources to exploit, as well as accidental misconfigurations by authorized users or administrators. Attack vectors may include direct access to misconfigured resources or leveraging misconfigurations to gain unauthorized access.
Impacts
The impacts of misconfigurations could include unauthorized access to sensitive data, service disruptions, data loss, compliance violations, and reputational damage to the organization.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker exploits a misconfigured storage account with publicly accessible data, leading to unauthorized access and exfiltration of sensitive information. In another scenario, an organization's virtual network misconfiguration allows an attacker to move laterally within the network and gain unauthorized access to critical systems.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1578 - Modify Cloud Compute Infrastructure

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-321
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-321: Use of Hard-coded Cryptographic Key The use of a hard-coded cryptographic key significantly increases the possibility that encrypted data may be recovered.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

weakness.name: CWE-922
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-922: Insecure Storage of Sensitive Information The product stores sensitive information without properly limiting read or write access by unauthorized actors. If read access is not properly restricted, then attackers can steal the sensitive information. If write access is not properly restricted, then attackers can modify and possibly delete the data, causing incorrect results and possibly a denial of service.

weakness.name: CWE-923
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-923: Improper Restriction of Communication Channel to Intended Endpoints The product establishes a communication channel to (or from) an endpoint for privileged or protected operations, but it does not properly ensure that it is communicating with the correct endpoint.

countermeasure.name: Enable network logging for security investigation
countermeasure.desc:
Enable and collect network security group (NSG) resource logs, NSG flow logs, Azure Firewall logs, and Web Application Firewall (WAF) logs, and logs from virtual machines via the network traffic data collection agent for security analysis to support incident investigations, and security alert generation. You can send the flow logs to an Azure Monitor Log Analytics workspace and then use Traffic Analytics to provide insights.
Collect DNS query logs to assist in correlating other network data.

countermeasure.name: Establish network segmentation boundaries
countermeasure.desc:
Create a virtual network (VNet) as a fundamental segmentation approach in your Azure network, so resources such as VMs can be deployed into the VNet within a network boundary. To further segment the network, you can create subnets inside VNet for smaller sub-networks.
Use network security groups (NSG) as a network layer control to restrict or monitor traffic by port, protocol, source IP address, or destination IP address. Refer to NS-7 Simplify network security configuration to use Adaptive Network Hardening to recommend NSG hardening rules based on threat intelligence and traffic analysis result.
You can also use application security groups (ASGs) to simplify complex configuration. Instead of defining policy based on explicit IP addresses in network security groups, ASGs enable you to configure network security as a natural extension of an application's structure, allowing you to group virtual machines and define network security policies based on those groups.

countermeasure.name: Follow just enough administration (least privilege) principle
countermeasure.desc:
Use Azure role-based access control (Azure RBAC) to manage Azure resource access through role assignments. Through RBAC, you can assign roles to users, groups, service principals, and managed identities. There are pre-defined built-in roles for certain resources, and these roles can be inventoried or queried through tools such as Azure CLI, Azure PowerShell, and the Azure portal.
The privileges you assign to resources through Azure RBAC should always be limited to what's required by the roles. Limited privileges will complement the just-in-time (JIT) approach of Azure AD Privileged Identity Management (PIM), and those privileges should be reviewed periodically. If required, you can also use PIM to define a time-bound assignment, which is a condition in a role assignment where a user can only activate the role within the specified start and end dates.
Note: Use Azure built-in roles to allocate permissions and only create custom roles when required.

countermeasure.name: Manage application identities securely and automatically
countermeasure.desc:
Use Azure managed identities, which can authenticate to Azure services and resources that support Azure AD authentication. Managed identity credentials are fully managed, rotated, and protected by the platform, avoiding hard-coded credentials in source code or configuration files.
For services that don't support managed identities, use Azure AD to create a service principal with restricted permissions at the resource level. It is recommended to configure service principals with certificate credentials and fall back to client secrets for authentication.

countermeasure.name: Restrict resource access based on conditions
countermeasure.desc:
Use Azure AD conditional access for more granular access controls based on user-defined conditions, such as requiring user logins from certain IP ranges (or devices) to use MFA. Azure AD Conditional Access allows you to enforce access controls on your organizations apps based on certain conditions.
Define the applicable conditions and criteria for Azure AD conditional access in the workload. Consider the following common use cases: - Requiring multi-factor authentication for users with administrative roles - Requiring multi-factor authentication for Azure management tasks - Blocking sign-ins for users attempting to use legacy authentication protocols - Requiring trusted locations for Azure AD Multi-Factor Authentication registration - Blocking or granting access from specific locations - Blocking risky sign-in behaviors - Requiring organization-managed devices for specific applications
Note: Granular authentication session management controls can also be implemented through Azure AD conditional access policies such as sign-in frequency and persistent browser session.

countermeasure.name: Secure cloud native services with network controls
countermeasure.desc:
Deploy private endpoints for all Azure resources that support the Private Link feature, to establish a private access point for the resources. Using Private Link will keep the private connection from routing through the public network.
Note: Certain Azure services may also allow private communication through the service endpoint feature, though it is recommended to use Azure Private Link for secure and private access to services hosted on Azure platform.
For certain services, you can choose to deploy VNet integration for the service where you can restrict/isolate the VNET to establish a private access point for the service.
You also have the option to configure the service native network ACL rules or simply disable public network access to block access from the public network.
For Azure VMs, unless there is a strong use case, you should avoid assigning public IPs/subnet directly to the VM interface and instead use gateway or load balancer services as the front-end for access by the public network.

countermeasure.name: Use a secure key management process
countermeasure.desc:
Use Azure Key Vault to create and control your encryption keys life cycle, including key generation, distribution, and storage. Rotate and revoke your keys in Azure Key Vault and your service based on the defined schedule and when there is a key retirement or compromise. Require a certain cryptographic type and minimum key size when generating keys.
When there is a need to use customer-managed key (CMK) in the workload services or applications, ensure you follow the best practices: - Use a key hierarchy to generate a separate data encryption key (DEK) with your key encryption key (KEK) in your key vault. - Ensure keys are registered with Azure Key Vault and implemented via key IDs in each service or application.
To maximize the key material lifetime and portability, bring your own key (BYOK) to the services (i.e., importing HSM-protected keys from your on-premises HSMs into Azure Key Vault). Follow the recommended guideline to perform the key generation and key transfer.
Note: Refer to the below for the FIPS 140-2 level for Azure Key Vault types and FIPS compliance/validation level. - Software-protected keys in vaults (Premium & Standard SKUs): FIPS 140-2 Level 1 - HSM-protected keys in vaults (Premium SKU): FIPS 140-2 Level 2 - HSM-protected keys in Managed HSM: FIPS 140-2 Level 3 Azure Key Vault Premium uses a shared HSM infrastructure in the backend. Azure Key Vault Managed HSM uses dedicated, confidential service endpoints with a dedicated HSM for when you need a higher level of key security.

countermeasure.name: Use centralized identity and authentication system
countermeasure.desc:
Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) is Azure's identity and authentication management service. You should standardize on Azure AD to govern your organization's identity and authentication in: - Microsoft cloud resources, such as Azure Storage, Azure Virtual Machines (Linux and Windows), Azure Key Vault, PaaS, and SaaS applications. - Your organization's resources, such as applications on Azure, third-party applications running on your corporate network resources, and third-party SaaS applications. - Your enterprise identities in Active Directory by synchronization to Azure AD to ensure a consistent and centrally managed identity strategy.
For the Azure services that apply, avoid use of local authentication methods and instead use Azure Active Directory to centralize your service authentications.
Note: As soon as it is technically feasible, you should migrate on-premises Active Directory-based applications to Azure AD. This could be an Azure AD Enterprise Directory, Business to Business configuration, or Business to consumer configuration.
